title: She’s running Boston to raise money for Homes For Our Troops
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: Rebecca Ludwig is running the 2026 Boston Marathon to raise funds for Homes For Our Troops.
Homes For Our Troops builds mortgage-free, accessible homes for severely injured veterans to regain independence.
Ludwig's Boston Marathon campaign supports home design, construction, and financial planning for veteran beneficiaries.

title: Lawmakers urge Healey to  prepare for possible state prosecutions of federal officials
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Twenty-three Massachusetts senators urged Gov. Maura Healey to prepare for state prosecutions of federal officials for misconduct.
Lawmakers proposed creating a task force, issuing guidance for local police, and developing a complaint portal for federal abuses.
Gov. Healey recently restricted ICE's operations, including barring ICE from schools and prohibiting civil arrests in state buildings.

title: She’s running Boston to honor her sister — and the hospital that treated her
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: Hannah Murray from Malden is running the 2026 Boston Marathon to honor her late sister, Grace.
Grace was treated for glioblastoma at Dana-Farber for two years before passing away at age 24.
Hannah is fundraising for Dana-Farber, with the marathon coinciding with Grace's 30th birthday.

title: Advocates, officials welcome judge’s move to block end of protections for Haitian immigrants
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Federal Judge Ana Reyes blocked the termination of Temporary Protected Status for Haitian immigrants, affecting 350,000 people nationwide.
The ruling allows Haitians to remain in the U.S. as conditions in Haiti worsen due to gang violence and a humanitarian crisis.
Massachusetts Gov. Maura Healey highlighted the vital role of Haitian TPS holders in health care and home care sectors.

title: What Robert Spillane and Harold Landry said about their injury statuses
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Harold Landry plans to play in the Super Bowl after missing the AFC Championship with a knee injury.
Robert Spillane aims to participate in the Super Bowl despite a recent ankle injury from the AFC Championship.
Both Landry and Spillane did not practice last week and are listed as questionable for the game.

title: Hundreds of apartments proposed for former Weylu’s site
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Developers plan 300-unit rental complex at former Weylu's site on Route 1 in Saugus, facing potential zoning challenges.
Saugus surpasses 10% affordable housing threshold, potentially enabling the Zoning Board to invoke 'Safe Harbor' and deny the project.
Residents oppose the development due to traffic concerns and potential impacts on historic homes, leading to a contentious hearing.

title: Ski Etiquette 101: What are your top do’s and don’ts for skiers and riders?
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: Skiers and snowboarders should adhere to the NSAA's Your Responsibility Code for safety on the slopes.
Chairlift etiquette issues include lowering bars in Vermont, littering, smoking, and playing loud music.
Lodge complaints involve the monopolization of tables and chairs with unattended bags and gear.

title: PETA sues over Mass. wiretap laws, saying they impede animal cruelty investigations
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: PETA is suing Massachusetts over its wiretap law, claiming it hinders investigations into animal cruelty.
The lawsuit filed in federal district court names Attorney General Andrea Campbell and District Attorney Anthony Gulluni as defendants.
PETA seeks exemptions for undercover investigations, arguing current laws deter documenting animal mistreatment and public concern topics.

title: Ben Affleck teases Dunkin’ Super Bowl commercial with stars of ‘Seinfeld,’ ‘Friends’
author: Kevin Slane
bullets: Ben Affleck stars with '90s sitcom icons in 2026 Dunkin' Super Bowl ad, marking his fourth year in Dunkin' ads.
The commercial features Jennifer Aniston, Jason Alexander, and Matt LeBlanc reacting to a '90s VHS pilot described as 'monstah cringe.'
Produced by Affleck and Damon’s Artists Equity, past Dunkin' ads included stars like Tom Brady, Casey Affleck, and Bill Belichick.

title: All the new movies and TV shows streaming in February
author: Kevin Slane
bullets: Streaming services feature romance films for Valentine's Day, including 'You've Got Mail' on Netflix and 'When Harry Met Sally' on HBO Max.
Black History Month prompts an increase in films by Black directors, such as 'Malcolm X' on HBO Max and 'Selma' on Peacock.
New films debuting in February include 'Kiss of the Spider Woman' on Hulu and 'Eternity' on Apple TV.
